title: 104_hr1385
content: The Act titled "Veterans Health Care Reform Act of 1995" establishes a health care reform program. The "Veterans Health Care Reform Act of 1995" establishes a program to reform the management of health care delivery to veterans by expanding outpatient care capacity and allocating resources to provide access to care regardless of the veterans' state of residence. The "Veterans Health Care Reform Act of 1995" aims to provide hospital care and outpatient medical treatment to veterans without regard to their state of residence. The Secretary is required to manage health care facilities to reduce duplication of services and realign programs. The "Veterans Health Care Reform Act of 1995" ensures veterans receive preventive health services, prosthetic appliances, and home care. The Secretary coordinates care through facilities and may establish rules for acquiring needed services. The Secretary may use patient prioritization systems and establish an enrollment program for eligible veterans to manage care provision. The Department must maintain capacity for specialized treatment of disabled veterans, ensuring reasonable access to care and services. The Department must maintain capacity for specialized treatment of disabled veterans, ensuring reasonable access to care and services. A veteran referred to in subsection (c)(1)(A) is any veteran with a compensable service-connected disability, whose discharge was for a compensable disability incurred in the line of duty, and who is entitled to disability compensation. The Department must ensure access to specialized treatment for disabled veterans. Eligible veterans include those with compensable service-connected disabilities entitled to disability compensation. The Secretary must report on the program's administration by February 1, 1999, with recommendations for legislation to expand access to healthcare services. This section expires on September 30. This section will expire on September 30, 1999. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. The Secretary must implement the program under section 1705 of title 38, United States Code by October 1, 1996. The amendment to section 1729 of title 38, United States Code allows for expenses related to establishing new outpatient clinics and increasing outpatient visits for eligible veterans. Additionally, a reserve fund is created for these purposes. A reserve fund is set aside annually with specific amounts allocated, and funds can only be used up to the available unobligated amounts. The reserve amount on December 1, 1995, is calculated based on the unobligated balance in the Fund, minus expenses, exceeding $579,282,000. On December 1, 1996, the reserve fund amount is calculated based on the unobligated balance in the Fund, minus expenses, exceeding $640,918,000. On December 1, 1997, the reserve fund amount is calculated based on the unobligated balance in the Fund, minus expenses, exceeding $731,334,000. On December 1, 1998, a new reserve amount will be set aside. On December 1, 1998, the reserve fund amount is determined by subtracting the unobligated balance in the Fund on September 30, 1998, from $758,321,000. On December 1, 1999, the reserve fund amount is calculated similarly, using the unobligated balance on September 30, 1999, and $372,435,000. The Secretary shall deposit the unobligated balance of the Fund into the Treasury as miscellaneous receipts annually by January 1, minus necessary expenses. Regulations will be prescribed for allocating reserve amounts to incentivize recoveries and collections, with up to 25% available for this purpose. The regulations allow for up to 25 percent of recovered funds to be directly allocated to medical centers with above-average recoveries, while the rest is distributed based on a plan targeting areas with the greatest need for outpatient care. The Under Secretary for Health conducts an annual study to assess capacity needs for outpatient care. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on medical care cost recovery, including details on the plan, regulations, allocations, and actions taken the previous fiscal year.
